name: Trappist-1 b
subtitle: A potentially rocky world, larger than Earth
description: TRAPPIST-1 b is a rocky exoplanet orbiting the ultra-cool dwarf star TRAPPIST-1, located approximately 40 light-years from Earth. With a mass of approximately 1.374 times that of Earth and a size of 1.116 times that of Earth, this planet completes one orbit around its star in 1.51 days. It was discovered in 2016 as part of a seven-planet system.

icons.title: Rocks
icons.description: Mostly rocky surface, with silicate compounds, similar to the terrestrial planets.

icons.title: Lava
icons.description: Its proximity to the star makes it an extremely hot planet, with temperatures that could melt rocks.

icons.title: High temperature
icons.description: There is speculation that there may be active volcanoes, which would imply possible lava flows on the surface.

icons.title: Vegetation
icons.description: There is speculation that there could be wild flora within the planet

icons.title: Freeze
icons.description: There is red ice caused by low temperatures and red radiation from its star

name: Trappist-1 c
subtitle: A potentially rocky world, larger than Earth
description: TRAPPIST-1 c is a rocky exoplanet that also orbits the ultra-cool dwarf star TRAPPIST-1, located 40 light-years from Earth. With a mass of 1,310 times that of Earth and a size of 1,097 times that of Earth, this planet completes an orbit in 2.42 days.

icons.title: Rocks
icons.description: Mostly rocky surface, with silicate compounds, similar to the terrestrial planets.

icons.title: Lava
icons.description: Its proximity to the star makes it an extremely hot planet, with temperatures that could melt rocks.

icons.title: Rainsstorm
icons.description: The presence of thunderstorms and rain is frequent on the exoplanet

icons.title: Vegetation
icons.description: There is speculation that there could be wild flora within the planet

icons.title: Freeze
icons.description: The side opposite its star has large amounts of ice on its surface, including icy mountains.

name: Trappist-1 d
subtitle: A rocky world, outside our Solar System
description: TRAPPIST-1 d is another rocky exoplanet that is part of the TRAPPIST-1 system, located 40 light-years from Earth. With an estimated mass of 0.388 times that of Earth and a size of 0.784 times that of Earth, TRAPPIST-1 d completes its orbit in 4.05 days.

icons.title: Winds
icons.description: Due to the interaction between its atmosphere and stellar radiation, there could be strong winds.

icons.title: Fire
icons.description: Its proximity to the star makes it an extremely hot planet, with temperatures that could melt rocks.

icons.title: Rainsstorm
icons.description: The presence of thunderstorms and rain is frequent on the exoplanet

icons.title: Freeze
icons.description: The coldest areas of the planet are likely to have ice, especially in areas far from direct radiation

icons.title: Rocks
icons.description: Presence of high rocky mountains with rock peaks, some even covered in ice

name: Trappist-1 e
subtitle: A rocky world, outside our Solar System
description: TRAPPIST-1 e is a rocky exoplanet orbiting the star TRAPPIST-1 at a distance of approximately 40 light-years from Earth. With a mass of 0.692 times that of Earth and a size of 0.910 times that of Earth, this planet completes its orbit in 6.1 days. TRAPPIST-1 e is located in the habitable zone of the star, which increases the possibility of the existence of liquid water.

icons.title: Thunder
icons.description: Thunderstorms are quite common on its surface due to the sudden changes in temperature.

icons.title: Fire
icons.description: Its proximity to the star makes it an extremely hot planet, with temperatures that could melt rocks.

icons.title: Clouds
icons.description: The planet could have a clear sky with sporadic clouds or cloudy areas

icons.title: Water
icons.description: one of the most promising planets in terms of the possibility of liquid oceans or bodies of water on its surface

icons.title: Rocks
icons.description: Is located in the habitable zone of its system. This suggests the possibility of a solid surface composed of silicates and common minerals.
